section.title: Configuration
section.p: There are many parameters and options that can be set to control the way in which Saxon behaves. For a comprehensive guide to the Saxon configuration features see the Saxon 9.9 documentation.
section.aside: Note that a small number of the features are not available with Saxon/C. Please see the Technical Information Limitations section for details.
section.p: In the Saxon/C API in C++, PHP and Python, these configuration features can be set at a global level when the SaxonProcessor is created, using the setConfigurationProperty() method. For example:
section.h2: Setting properties on the specific processors
section.p: Alternatively, the configuration features can be set on the XSLT, XQuery, XPath or XML Schema processors (XsltProcessor, XQueryProcessor, etc.) created from the main SaxonProcessor. See the following sections for details about which properties and parameters can be configured in the different XSLT, XQuery, XPath or XML Schema processors, using the setProperty() and setParameter() methods. Depending on the specific processor the exact purpose of these methods may differ. Further details can be found in the Saxon/C API documentation.

section.title: XSLT processors
section.p: Details about parameters and properties which can be set on an XsltProcessor or Xslt30Processor.

td.p: Sets the source document for the transformation to the XdmNode supplied.
Sets the value of a stylesheet parameter.

section.p: The properties available are a subset to those specified for running XSLT from the command line (see the Saxon 9.9 documentation for more information).

td.p: Influence the serialization of the result output. Serialization parameters are specified by name, preceded by a leading exclamation mark (!). This is equivalent to specifying the corresponding attribute (e.g. indent="yes") on an xsl:output declaration in the stylesheet. An output parameter specified on the command line overrides one specified within the stylesheet.
Set the destination for the result of the transformation to the specified filename.
Set the initial template for the transformation by name.
Set whether or not DTD validation should be applied to documents loaded.
Set the initial mode for the transformation.
Identifies the source file or directory.
Specifies the directory where the resources files are found.

tr.td: XSLT 3.0 only. Accepts the values "true", "false", "yes", "no". Set to true if the initial template parameter values are to be used for setting tunnel parameters; or false if they are to be used for non-tunnel parameters.

XSLT 3.0 only. Accepts the values "true", "false", "yes", "no". Set to true if the transform invocation methods are to return the raw XdmValue result, otherwise the result is returned as an XdmNode object with a Document node as its root.

td.p: Specifies the full path to the Saxon/C API library for extension functions. (For more information on extension functions, see Extension Functions in C++/PHP.)

tr.td: Creates a message listener which is available in the Saxon/C API.

section.title: XQuery processor
section.p: Details about parameters and properties which can be set on an XQueryProcessor.

td.p: Sets the context item for the query to the XdmNode supplied.
Sets the value of an external variable defined in the query.

section.p: The properties available are a subset to those specified for running XQuery from the command line (see the Saxon 9.9 documentation for more information).

td.p: Influence the serialization of the result output. Serialization parameters are specified by name, preceded by a leading exclamation mark (!). This is equivalent to specifying the corresponding output declaration (e.g. declare option output:indent "yes";) in the query prolog.
Set the static base URI for a query. This is used to resolve any relative URIs appearing within a query.

td.code: Identifies the file containing the query.

td.p: Allows the query to be specified inline.
Sets the destination for the result of the XQuery to the specified filename.
Set whether or not DTD validation should be applied to documents loaded.
Identifies the source file or directory.
Specifies the directory where the resources files are found.
Invoke a schema-aware query. Requires Saxon-EE/C.
Specifies the full path to the Saxon/C API library for extension functions. (For more information on extension functions, see Extension Functions in C++/PHP.)

section.title: XPath processor
section.p: Details about parameters and properties which can be set on an XPathProcessor.

td.p: Sets the context item for the XPath expression to the XdmNode supplied.
Sets the value of an external variable defined in the XPath expression.

Influence the serialization of the result output. Serialization parameters are specified by name, preceded by a leading exclamation mark (!). This is equivalent to specifying the corresponding attribute on an xsl:output declaration in a stylesheet, or the corresponding output declaration in a query prolog.
Sets the destination for the result of evaluating the XPath expression to the specified filename.
Sets whether or not DTD validation should be applied to documents loaded.
Identifies the source file or directory.
Specifies the directory where the resources files are found.
Specifies the full path to the Saxon/C API library for extension functions. (For more information on extension functions, see Extension Functions in C++/PHP.)

section.title: Schema Validator
section.p: Details about parameters and properties which can be set on a SchemaValidator.

td.p: Sets the source document for the validation.
Sets the value of a Saxon extension parameter defined in the schema (see Parameterizing Schemas in the Saxon 9.9 documentation for more information).

section.p: The properties available are a subset to those specified for running schema validation from the command line (see the Saxon 9.9 documentation for more information).

td.p: Influence the serialization of the result output. Serialization parameters are specified by name, preceded by a leading exclamation mark (!). This is equivalent to specifying the corresponding attribute on an xsl:output declaration in a stylesheet, or the corresponding output declaration in a query prolog.
Sets the destination for the result of the validation to the specified filename.
Sets the source document for validation as a string. Parsing will happen when the validate method has been called.
Set whether or not DTD validation should be applied to documents loaded.
Identifies the source file or directory.
Specifies the directory where the resources files are found.
Switches on the validation reporting feature. Validation failure errors are represented in an XML document.
Switches on the validation reporting feature. Validation failure errors are collected and saved in an XML file.
Set verbose mode to output to the terminal validation exceptions. The default is on providing the reporting feature has not been enabled.
Set the name of the required type of the top-level element of the document to be validated. The string should be in the Clark notation: {uri}local.
Set the name of the required top-level element of the document to be validated (that is, the name of the outermost element of the document). The string should be in the Clark notation: {uri}local.
The validation mode may be either strict or lax. The default is strict. This property indicates that lax validation is required.
